Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I settled into my armchair, the new law review journal in my lap. I’d been waiting all week for this issue, eager to dive into the latest articles on emerging legal theories—keeping up with these developments is crucial for my work as a judge. But the call was from Sam, my oldest friend, his voice tight with panic. He was on his way to the airport and thought he’d left his passport at home. “Can you check and, if it’s here, bring it to me? My flight’s in two hours,” he pleaded.

As a friend, I knew what was expected—drop everything, help out, be there in a crisis. But as a judge, I felt the weight of my professional responsibility: I needed to stay current, to read and reflect, to be prepared for the cases coming up next week. The journal’s pages seemed to grow heavier in my hands as I listened to Sam’s anxious breathing. My mind raced, torn between the urgent needs of a friend and the unyielding demands of my role on the bench.
